climbs.name: Up, Jump, Spring
climbs.fa: Mike Baca and Graham B, July 1989

content.description: Very fun route!  Small holds and protection appear just as you really need them.  Starts just right of Spring Honeymoon, under the right of two small roofs.  You can set a bomber nut about 2/3 the way to the first (high) bolt.  The climbing is easy until the first bolt, and then becomes much more interesting, and better protected.
content.protection: Bolts + Pro to 1".  There are several good nut placements on this route.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the Center Left of Spring Dome.

content.description:
Starts a short distance uphill (left) from Double Double, below the left of two small roofs.

This was a fun route, and a bit "sporty".  The crux seemed to be about 2/3 the way to the top, just before gaining a hand crack.
content.location: This route is located on the Center Left of Spring Dome.

climbs.name: Southern California Drill Team
climbs.fa: J. Gonzales, Dale Barringer, Sandy Huse, Novak, 1992

content.protection: Seven bolts and potential for a small Tricam. Crux on thin slab just below the anchor protected by a retro bolt approved by FA. Two bolt anchor with screw links. A 70m rope barely reaches ground if rappelling.
content.location: From the toe of the wall, walk along the base to the left; as you start ascending, look right for the line of bolts leading to the anchor.

content.description: 2 pitch route that starts to the left of Double Double. Start moves to the first bolt on the first pitch and the first bolt on the second pitch are the crux moves of the route.
content.protection: Bolts and Pro .5" to 2" Bolted anchors.
content.location: Start of this route is left of Double Double.

climbs.name: Mini-Dike Overpass
climbs.fa: James Weger, Bob Lindgren & Tim Hoover, July 1989

content.description: Start as for Double Double and Gerrytromp, but continue up the vertical crack until it ends. Make crux slab moves to first bolt. Continue on, clipping two more bolts and head towards vertical cracks above. Another short section of slab brings you to a wide crack which is followed to anchor / rap rings shared with Gerrytromp.
content.location: Shares start with Double Double and Gerrytromp. 1st bolt can be seen from the ground. Shares rappel anchor (150' to ground) with Gerrytromp.

content.description: Start the same as Boomerproof up the short overhang, but after the first couple of bolts cut right on the obvious crack. Difficult to get established into the crack followed by a strenuous traverse protected by bomber mostly finger-sized cams. The angle eases and the difficulty drops dramatically, but the gear also begins to disappear as you head up the slab to the large ledge marking the finish of the route where you can build a natural anchor with a few hand-sized pieces.
content.location: On the overhanging wall of Spring Dome's West Face. The route starts on Boomerproof's juggy flake and quickly cuts right traversing the crack. Start left of the route, "I Am Not A Bear!, I am a Marmot!"

content.description:
Marmotromp follows a right facing, right arching 5.8 crack that is a blast to engaging, varied and sustained face climbing past bolts and intermittent cracks above.

It is easy to miss the 5th bolt and follow a nice line of holds and crack right to the Joy Spring anchor, although another 5.10a/b friction crux is found getting to the 5th bolt.  Lower angle climbing leads to an anchor 15 feet higher going straight up.
content.protection: Light rack of nuts and cams from small to 2 inches, with a couple extra finger size cams.  5 good bolts with bolted rap anchor.  2 ropes needed to get down or 5 minute walk off north side.

content.description: Fun route that starts in a short right-facing crack before 3 bolts on slab.
content.protection: Single set of small and medium cams. 3 bolts. Gear anchor. Walk off.
content.location: First route to the left of the large left-facing corner (Big Daddy's Warm Up 5.5).

climbs.name: Joy Spring
climbs.fa: Mike Baca, F. Costic, R. Takahashi & B. Meyette, July 1989

content.description:
Joy Spring is another good mixed bolt / gear route on the west face of Spring Dome, just left of Spring Honeymoon.

Follow a fun 5.8 left facing flake as it arches left, climb up and past 3 bolts to fun cracks and a high, easy to miss 4th bolt directly below the anchor or head a little right to the Spring Honeymoon anchor.

Varied climbing with an exciting 5.9 friction section to the second bolt that will get your attention.
content.protection: Light rack of nuts and cams small to 2 inches and good bolts.  Bolted anchor/rap requires 2 ropes or walk off 5 minutes north side.

climbs.name: I am not a bear! I am a marmot!

content.description:
"Begin in an overhang to reach easier face with two bolts. Wander up through easier ground and build a belay on the ramping ledge."

Gymnastic off the deck. Clip the first bolt before setting off and have the belayer in a position to catch the initial whip. After the bolts, follow the dark water streak up to the large horizontal ledge to build the gear belay.
content.protection: 2 bolts and plenty of pockets for tricams after that. Gear anchor will work with BD #2's or #1 and .75 depending on where you build it. Walk off to climbers right is really easy.
content.location: Bolted route to the right of Boomerproof.

content.description: Short Â by fun hand/fist crack. The crack as well as the face on either side are well featured.
content.protection: Pro to 3". Bolted anchor without rap rings. Walk off.
content.location: 50 feet left of The Lizard of Oz 5.8. Route is the obvious hand/fist-sized crack.

climbs.name: Gerrytromp
climbs.fa: John G, Doug S, Fred C & Don P, July 1989

content.description:
Really nice moderate route. Start as for Double Double, except that after pulling right around the corner and onto the sloping ledge, follow a line of widely spaced bolts straight up. There are ten bolts and the opportunity to place gear in a couple short cracks.

No surprises on this route, it is sustained 5.8 friction on great rock.
content.protection: You can place a 0.75 Camalot if the first bolt is too high for you, otherwise 10 bolts to a 4 bolt anchor (2 new, 2 old).
content.location: This route is located on the Center Right of Spring Dome

climbs.name: Family Affair
climbs.fa: Pam Neal, Farah Alibay, Mary Lohrman, Randy Kirkpatrick, Don Porter, Anunzita & Ben Chapman.

content.description: Climb the beautiful, featured black water streak right of Southern California Drill Team on knobs and edges past 4 bolts to a large depression. At the top of the depression clip a bolt and stem up to a left leaning crack. Climb the crack using cams to protect fun moves up to final slab moves to the anchor. Family Affair is mixed route which constitutes clipping bolts and placing traditional gear.
content.location: 15 ft right of Southern California Drill Team.

content.description:
Start beneath a left facing corner downhill (right) from Up Jump Spring.

P1: Climb the left facing corner for about 15 feet until you can move right onto a sloping ledge.  Clip the first bolt of Gerrytromp, and continue right.  Follow a horizontal crack until a vertical crack intersects it.  Follow the vertical hand crack to a gear-belay beneath a right facing corner.

P2: Layback up the corner as it curves and becomes a roof.  Pass the roof on the right, then follow easier terrain up and left to the the 4 bolt anchor at the top of Gerrytromp.

Pitch 1 & 2 can be combined into a 200ft rope stretcher, but you had better be ready for some rope drag . . .
content.location: This route is located on the Center Right of Spring Dome.

content.description: Follows easy slab, water grooves and solution holes to the top of the dome.
content.location: Start on the water groove to the right of the Southern California drill team, follow the line of weakness through some solution pockets to the summit of Spring dome

climbs.name: Boomerproof
climbs.fa: Erik Wright, Josh Hood, Aaron Formella 09/02/2019

content.description:
If you think the route to the right is really a 10a, you should have no problem with this one. 10b?

This route offers fun, dynamic, and gymnastic moves on overhanging granite. It is well protected, approachable for the grade, and seems to be easier if you are tall.

Start on a left facing flake beneath the overhang, then, rather than continuing right along the crack, make a big move up and left onto a rail. Boulder your way up the steep face and stand up on the lip. Climb a short, fine quality, slab (5.7ish) up to a right-facing flake, pass several horizontal grooves, then run it out up the easy slab (5.5ish) to finish at a ledge with a horizontal crack where you can build an anchor.

The area is shaded in the morning before the sun comes around the dome, and in the afternoon the trees again offer shade.
content.protection:
4 bolts

Optional hand-sized cams for upper sections of climb

Hand-sized cams (#2 BD) for top anchor in horizontal crack  (#1 can also work)

If you want to TR or need to clean your anchor after lowering off, you can ascend the SW side of the dome and walk north along an exposed ledge system until you are above the route.
content.location: On the overhanging wall of Spring Dome's West Face. The route starts on a left facing flake at the bottom of a prominent right leaning crack. Left of the route, "I Am Not A Bear!, I am a Marmot!"
